Q: If energy cannot be created, how was the universe made? A: We don’t know. Q: Was there energy before the Big Bang? A: We don’t know. We don’t even know if there was a “before” the Big Bang, or whether the term “before the Big Bang” makes as little sense as “north of the North Pole”.  You see, the big problem is that we’re inside the universe. We don’t have a top-down view. We look at the Big Bang from the inside and backwards in time. To further complicate matters, there are several horizons between us and the Bang, the last one being the Planck epoch at the very earliest moment of the universe. At that epoch, the conditions of the universe were so extreme that we don’t have the physics to describe what happened. So we can’t – at the moment, at least – explain how the universe came to be or how the energy got there.  We can speculate, though. There are lots of speculations that proposes that there were universes before this, including Predecessor Black Holes and Conformal Cyclic Cosmology, both of which suggest that this universe got its energy from an earlier universe. And there is also the Zero Energy Universe hypothesis. It suggests that the total sum of energy and gravity in the universe is zero: if you take all energy and matter in the universe and sum it to one column, and then all gravitational potential in the other column, they may cancel out one another, leaving you with the tidy sum of zero. There are even some evidence in the large scale structure of the universe which support this wild idea. Although this model doesn’t tell us how the universe came to be, it does explain that it could come from nothing. In fact, it would still be nothing, only very unevenly distributed.
